to mark a specific diversity, and considering that these disks always
grow on the surfaces of other bodies, it can scarcely, I think, be considered
improbable, that the plications <s>are derived from</s> originate in the inflections of those
surfaces. [<u>Note.</u> I have elsewhere noticed the fact, that various
species of <u>Orbitoides</u> are disposed to exhibit a like contortion; and
that the well marked <u>ephippial</u> shape, which some specimens
present, are nothing else than accidental varieties (see "Quart Journ:
of Geol Soc" Vol vi pp 34, 35]  These same specimens, moreover, also
exhibit another curious abnormality, namely the projection of the
upper and lower edges of the margin, so that a groove is left between
them, the projecting laminae being thin and foliaceous, and their cells
very irregularly arranged. This peculiarity, again, being far from uniform
in its degree, and being altogether wanting in <s>the</s> specimens, which
in other respects precisely resemble those with plicated and
foliated margins, must be considered merely in the light of
accidental variety; but I cannot suggest any explanation of its
occurrence, or of its limitation (so far as I am aware) to this particular
locality.
